key_points: A Facebook engineer abused access to user data to track down a woman after a vacation dispute, reveals a new book.
"An Ugly Truth: Inside Facebook's Battle for Domination" reports 52 employees were fired between January 2014 and August 2015 for misusing user data.
The engineer located a woman by accessing her Facebook data, including her new hotel's location.
Another engineer accessed a date's conversations, events, photos, and real-time location after she ceased responding to him.
Facebook granted engineers extensive data access to streamline their work, relying on employee integrity to prevent misuse.
Most misuse cases involved male engineers accessing women's profiles they were interested in.
Facebook claims to have a zero-tolerance policy for data access abuse, stating they've fired every violator and strengthened safeguards since 2015.
Facebook's CEO, Mark Zuckerberg, became aware of these issues in September 2015, following a presentation by then-chief security officer Alex Stamos.
Stamos proposed significantly reducing the number of employees who could access user data, encountering executive resistance.
The book suggests Zuckerberg's inherent approach favored data collection growth over privacy.
spokespersons: Alex Stamos (Former Chief Security Officer, Facebook)
